III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• No technical assistance was requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultant spoke with Superintendent and Assistant Superintendent about
current open corrective action plans and past investigations. Superintendent
reported the facility has been making updates to all programs within the license
to make sure staff are being trained and following all new policy guidelines.
The facility is currently doing a review of all their current policies and
procedures to make sure there is compliance with state licensing
requirements, are trauma informed and follow with the guidelines of PREA and
Raise the Age. Superintendent reported they have created a policy committee
that includes direct care staff, shift supervisors, supervisors, administrators,
and treatment staff to review all the facility's policies for updates. The facility
plans to communicate with this consultant about any changes.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 2 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. There were 2 incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period. Special Investigation 2023C03280002 dated 10/20/2022
found the facility in non-compliance for rule 400.10107, employment policies and
procedures. A correction plan dated 12/01/2022 was approved that included the
staff member involved termination of employment and training for staff. Special
Investigation 2023C0000425 dated 04/25/2023 found the facility in non-
compliance for rule 400.10107, employment policies and procedures, rule
400.10127, compliance with child protection law, and rule 400.10123 (2), staff
sufficiency. A correction plan dated 07/06/2023 was approved that included the
staff member involved having disciplinary action and training for staff.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
facility has had 6 special investigations during this period under reviewed with 4
resulting in corrective action plans and 2 investigations still pending. The non-
compliance noted included staff not following the facility's personal boundary

policy, staff not following the suicidal precautions policy, staff not following the
shower supervision policy, facility not following staffing ratio and staff not
complying with child protection law. The facility's corrective action plan compliance
is monitored quarterly. The facility has been in compliance with meeting the
expectations of the set deadlines of action steps within their corrective action
plans.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Not Applicable
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. The staff reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well as
administration. They reported they see the administration staff come on the units
to help support staffing and the youth which has been beneficial. They reported
feeling an adequate amount of training and well versed in the restraint model
training. The staff indicated no concerns with restraints they observed or
participated in. Staff reported they has been thankful that they are involved with
reviewing the policies and procedures at the facility to make sure there is clear
input from direct care staff members.
Three youth were interviewed during the inspection and reported feeling safe at
the facility. The youth indicated no concerns with restraints they have observed or
been in with staff. They reported staff use verbal de-escalation prior and only go
hands on when the situation is not safe. All the youth reported they feel like the
level system is fair and gives them a goal to earn privileges. The youth were able
to talk about the grievances policy and noted the shift supervisors will always
come talk to them about the grievances. One of the youths noted they felt that
sometimes they are not taken seriously with their complaints, but they know how to
raise that to the administrators since they help out on the units.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on August 10, 2023.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
